comment.author: 8979614@N08
comment._content:
This is a view taken from the place de la Concorde towards the Place de la Madeleine (the Madeleine church is in the centre of the frame) along the axis of the Rue Royale.

I'm not sure how the buildings were used at the time. The left one is now the Hotel de Crillon, the right one is part of ministry or other official thing.

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Yes, the view is of what is currently the Hotel de Crillon on the left and the “Royale”, the headquarters of the French Navy at the head of the Rue Royale on the right, looking toward the Place de la Madeleine. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_de_Crillon en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%c3%89glise_de_la_Madeleine Thanks for the information! We will use it to update our catalog record.

comment.author: 82749847@N00
comment._content: Left is hotel de crillon and right is the actual HQ of the French Navy at that time it was the Ministere de la Marine (Navy Ministry) :-) here a view from rue royale in 1860: www.parisenimages.fr/fr/popup-photo.html?photo=5701-6 and here from the angle of Jardin des Tuileries www.notrefamille.com/cartes-postales-photos/cartes-postal... and an other angle in here - nearly the same one than your shot but more right of the building ! www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/memsmn_fr?ACTION=CHERC... de la guerre 1914-1918 et Paris cheers ! :-)

comment.author: 45884632@N08
comment._content: Hello, these buildings should be drawn by Ange-Jacques Gabriel, and are a first step towards neoclassical architecture in France. Since you seem to be ok with it I'll be using it for a class in the modern period in art history! Thanks :-)

comment.author: 89235234@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Renaud Camus - Journal d'un voyage en France, and we'd love to have this added to the group!
